form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Ms. Cantwell introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources

form.official-title: To provide for the modernization, security, and resiliency of the electric grid, to require the Secretary of Energy to carry out programs for research, development, demonstration, and information-sharing for cybersecurity for the energy sector, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Enhanced Grid Security Act of 2015.

paragraph.text: The term Department means the Department of Energy.
The term electric utility has the meaning given the term in section 3 of the Federal Power Act (16 U.S.C. 796).
The term ES-ISAC means the Electricity Sector Information Sharing and Analysis Center.
The term National Laboratory has the meaning given the term in section 2 of the Energy Policy Act of 2005 (42 U.S.C. 15801).
The term Secretary means the Secretary of Energy.
The term Sector-Specific Agency has the meaning given the term in the Presidential policy directive entitled Critical Infrastructure Security and Resilience, numbered 21, and dated February 12, 2013.

section.header: Designation of Department of Energy as Sector-Specific Agency for cybersecurity for the energy sector
section.text: In accordance with the Presidential policy directive entitled Critical Infrastructure Security and Resilience, numbered 21, and dated February 12, 2013, and this Act, the Department shall be the lead Sector-Specific Agency for cybersecurity for the energy sector.

section.header: Cybersecurity for the energy sector research, development, and demonstration program
section.text: The Secretary, in consultation with appropriate Federal agencies, the energy sector, the States, and other stakeholders, shall carry out a program—

paragraph.text: to develop advanced cybersecurity applications and technologies for the energy sector—

subparagraph.text: to identify and mitigate vulnerabilities, including—

clause.text: dependencies on other critical infrastructure; and
impacts from weather, climate change, and fuel supply; and

subparagraph.text: to advance the security of field devices and third-party control systems, including—

clause.text: systems for generation, transmission, distribution, end use, and market functions;
specific electric grid elements including advanced metering, demand response, distributed generation, and electricity storage;
forensic analysis of infected systems; and

paragraph.text: to leverage electric grid architecture as a means to assess risks to the energy sector, including by implementing an all-hazards approach to communications infrastructure, control systems architecture, and power systems architecture;
to perform pilot demonstration projects with the energy sector to gain experience with new technologies; and
to develop workforce development curricula for energy sector-related cybersecurity.

section.header: Energy sector component testing for cyberresilience program
section.text: The Secretary shall carry out a program—

paragraph.text: to establish a cybertesting and mitigation program to identify vulnerabilities of energy sector supply chain products to known threats;
to oversee third-party cybertesting; and
to develop procurement guidelines for energy sector supply chain components.

section.header: Energy sector operational support for cyberresilience program
section.text: The Secretary shall carry out a program—

paragraph.text: to enhance and periodically test—

subparagraph.text: the emergency response capabilities of the Department; and
the coordination of the Department with other agencies, the National Laboratories, and private industry;

paragraph.text: to expand cooperation of the Department with the intelligence communities for energy sector-related threat collection and analysis;
to enhance the tools of the Department and ES-ISAC for monitoring the status of the energy sector;
to expand industry participation in ES-ISAC; and
to provide technical assistance to small electric utilities for purposes of assessing cybermaturity posture.

section.header: Modeling and assessing energy infrastructure risk

subsection.text: The Secretary shall develop an advanced energy security program to secure energy networks, including electric, natural gas, and oil exploration, transmission, and delivery.

The objective of the program developed under subsection (a) is to increase the functional preservation of the electric grid operations or natural gas and oil operations in the face of natural and human-made threats and hazards, including electric magnetic pulse and geomagnetic disturbances.
In carrying out the program developed under subsection (a), the Secretary may—

paragraph.text: develop capabilities to identify vulnerabilities and critical components that pose major risks to grid security if destroyed or impaired;
provide modeling at the national level to predict impacts from natural or human-made events;
develop a maturity model for physical security and cybersecurity;
conduct exercises and assessments to identify and mitigate vulnerabilities to the electric grid, including providing mitigation recommendations;
conduct research hardening solutions for critical components of the electric grid;
conduct research mitigation and recovery solutions for critical components of the electric grid; and
provide technical assistance to States and other entities for standards and risk analysis.

section.text: The programs established under this Act shall be carried out consistent with—

paragraph.text: the report of the Department entitled Roadmap to Achieve Energy Delivery Systems Cybersecurity and dated 2011;
existing programs of the Department; and
any associated strategic framework that links together academic and National Laboratory researchers, electric utilities, manufacturers, and any other relevant private industry organizations.

subsection.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary, in consultation with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the North American Electric Reliability Corporation, shall conduct a study to explore alternative management structures and funding mechanisms to expand industry membership and participation in ES-ISAC.
The Secretary shall submit to the appropriate committees of Congress a report describing the results of the study conducted under subsection (a).

section.text: There is authorized to be appropriated to carry out this Act $100,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2017 through 2022.
